name: NewYorker
text: "The statues are being toppled, but the story that built them remains," the historian David W. Blight writes. "If this is to be our 1989, we must make the most of it. The whole world may be watching." https://t.co/dG2vhOA8zJ

name: NewYorker
text: Making ice cream typically involves not only a machine but more than a day of preparation; the plastic-bag method simplifies things and doubles as a party trick. https://t.co/G2u6ZaBgcE

name: NewYorker
text: Revisit @JeffreyToobin's 2008 Profile of Roger Stone. https://t.co/tyqKdlJyuE

name: NewYorker
text:
In a new story by Etgar Keret—the first installment of our summer 2020 Flash Fiction series—a director sets out to make a film that is 73 years long.
https://t.co/Ssx3mraCQg

name: NewYorker
text: Wanna open up your closet tonight? https://t.co/aINB4bXVww

name: NewYorker
text: A new documentary short by @alxmallis follows two parents who use gender-neutral pronouns and outfits in order to shield their one-year-old from the gender pressures exerted on young children. Watch here. https://t.co/W3ls8PT4BY

name: NewYorker
text: For half a century, the particulars of Flannery O’Connor’s bigotry have been held close by executors, smoothed over by editors, and justified by exegetes, as if to save O’Connor from herself. https://t.co/Eo6zDP7jlF

name: NewYorker
text: The elaborate nail stylings made popular by black women have been both derided and appropriated. In a new documentary, they’re honored as art. https://t.co/mqj6KXmo5C

name: NewYorker
text: The ultimate conclusion of the Commission on the Freedom of the Press, which first met in 1943, remains a bracing admonition: that the responsibility for fixing the press must fall most heavily upon the press itself. https://t.co/P33BoCCsjz

name: NewYorker
text: The lynching of a man named Robert Edwards, in 1912, inaugurated a decades-long reign of terror in Forsyth County, Georgia. In “Blood at the Root,” Patrick Phillips delves into his home town’s violent history—and asks what we can do today. https://t.co/ObU4CmJKfa

name: NewYorker
text: The designer Willi Smith brought a democratic flair to his creations, selling his patterns so that anyone could bring them to life, and packaging them with illustrations of both men and women sporting the same finished product. https://t.co/pmapNja1MZ

name: NewYorker
text: “At Occupy City Hall, organizers have set up talks and teach-ins in a safe and responsible manner,” @mashagessen writes. “Colleges ought to be asking young people like them how to bring that knowledge, and that sense of care and responsibility, to campus.” https://t.co/PMNBRvO34Q

name: NewYorker
text:
As bad as President Trump’s invective is on Twitter and elsewhere, the actions of the Justice Department under William Barr are worse, because individuals and communities will be paying the costs for years, or decades, to come.
 https://t.co/oi5slBuygo

name: NewYorker
text: Escape the heat with a selection of pieces about summer vacations from the #NewYorkerArchive. https://t.co/ycCBxtn4na

name: NewYorker
text: Sarah Shun-lien Bynum’s new novella explores the fraught and intimate friendship between three girls as they become young women. https://t.co/2QqWGwLBDy
